title: Why a16z VC believes that Cluely, the ‘cheat on everything' startup, is the new blueprint for AI startups
original_content: When Cluely, a startup claiming to be building a product that helps people “cheat” on everything, announced that it raised a $15 million Series A financing round from Andreessen Horowitz, some people on X criticized the VC firm for backing the controversial company. After all, Cluely isn’t just offering a product that may have questionable uses; the startup has also become famous for using what many people call rage-bait marketing. But Cluely’s ability to grab attention is precisely what attracted a16z to the startup. Even before meeting Cluely’s founder Roy Lee, Andreessen Horowitz’s partner Bryan Kim thought that startups need new marketing tactics in the AI era. Kim, like many investors, previously thought that building a superb “artisan” product with highly desired features was the key to a startup’s lasting success, he explained on the latest a16z podcast episode . But shortly after the emergence of generative AI, he noticed that offering an exceptional product might not be enough. “If you craft this thing and OpenAI or someone builds a new model to include that part in their product, you’re done,” Kim said. “So, it couldn’t become this highly thoughtful, slow-build product. Earlier this month, Kim published a post explaining his theory of why, for consumer-facing AI startups, “momentum is the moat.” When Kim met Lee and saw that Cluely had been able to convert awareness into paying customers, he instantly knew that he had discovered a founder he had theorized about. “It’s been so hard to pierce through the noise of everything AI, especially in consumer, and to do that consistently is actually near impossible,” Kim said. How does Lee explain why his polarizing marketing approach has generated so much buzz? “Most people don’t know how to make viral content,” Lee said on the podcast. “Everyone on X is trying to [sound] like the most intellectual, thoughtful person. tiktok_summary: The controversy that's tearing the tech world apart: Cluely, the 'cheat on everything' startup that just landed a $15 million investment from Andreessen Horowitz! Imagine being able to cheat your way to success... Sounds too good to be true? That's exactly what Cluely claims to offer - a product that helps you "cheat" on everything. And yes, that includes dating, job interviews, and even academic cheating. But here's the thing: Cluely isn't just a regular ol' cheater app. It's a masterclass in marketing. I mean, who needs subtlety when you can just go full-on provocative and grab attention? Wait, what? You're thinking Cluely sounds like a scam artist? Well, think again! They've got the juice - a $15 million Series A funding from none other than Andreessen Horowitz. The same venture capital firm behind some of the most iconic tech companies out there. Now, you're probably wondering why a16z would take a chance on Cluely. Well, let me tell you - it's not because they're looking for another "superb artisan" product. In fact, their partner Bryan Kim has been saying that offering top-notch products just won't cut it anymore. He thinks we need something new - something bold, something that grabs attention. Cluely's founders have mastered the art of rage-bait marketing. They're so good at getting people talking, they've become infamous for it. So, who's responsible for this genius strategy? None other than their fearless leader, Roy Lee. Here's where things get really spicy: Cluely's product is more than just a tool for cheating. It's a reflection of our times.
